title: 108_s3024
content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the appointment of a Director of National Transportation Research. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding, resources for transportation research and development have remained stagnant. There is a need for more funding and a focus on long-term strategic research through competitive, peer-reviewed awards. The diversity of transportation research programs presents challenges in addressing the needs of different customers. To address the challenges in transportation research, it is crucial to increase Federal investment in long-range planning, support competitive research, coordinate DOT programs, and facilitate data exchange among stakeholders. Establish nationwide priorities in Federal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The Center's duties include establishing nationwide priorities in Federal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is tasked with developing a long-term national policy for research and development in multimodal transportation, supporting projects with public benefits, awarding grants for strategic transportation objectives, and facilitating the exchange of research data among interested parties in the United States. The National Center for Transportation Solutions serves as a hub for transportation research and development in the US, consults with the Department of Transportation, coordinates research programs, evaluates government research programs, and submits annual reports to Congress with recommendations on multimodal transportation research. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board discusses minority views and recommendations related to multimodal transportation. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board focuses on minority views and recommendations in multimodal transportation. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board, established by this Act, consists of the Director of National Transportation Research and 16 voting members appointed by various authorities. Members must represent diverse professions and sectors in the public and private domains. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board, established by this Act, consists of 16 voting members appointed by various authorities. Members must represent diverse professions and possess appropriate skills and experience. Initial appointments should be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with staggered terms of six, four, and two years for members. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members with staggered terms of six, four, and two years. The term of a member shall not expire during an election year. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the Chair with a majority required for a quorum. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members with staggered terms. A majority constitutes a quorum for hearings. The Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members for 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms as Chairman. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board appoints a Director of National Transportation Research, who serves as the chief executive officer, carries out the Center's authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Director serves a six-year term and receives a salary not exceeding the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Center's organization is outlined in Section 7. The Center is organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division has a committee composed of at least five members serving two-year terms, with an annually elected Chairman. Each division committee elects a Chairman from its members and sets its own procedures within Board restrictions. The Center has powers as outlined in Section 8. The Board and division committees have the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, enter into contracts, and use postal services to carry out the purposes of the Act. They may also secure information directly from federal departments or agencies as needed. The Board and division committees have the authority to gather information, enter contracts, and use postal services. They may also accept gifts and publish research results. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director has the authority to appoint and terminate staff for the Center without following civil service laws. The staff's responsibilities include submitting strategic and annual plans, developing budgets, administering programs, providing support to the Board, and coordinating with other departments. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for personnel is determined by the Director, and government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement. The Director can also procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint staff under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Volunteer services can be accepted without following certain regulations. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director shall award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States. These centers will conduct research on long-term multimodal transportation issues with public benefits and where private investment is necessary. The northeast regional center will be located in one of the top 5 states with high traffic congestion on National Highway System roads. The State must have a high ratio of annual vehicle miles traveled on National Highway System roads to the number of lane miles in the State. It must also be one of the top 10 States with high traffic congestion based on the ratio of urban road miles to urban lane miles on the National Highway System. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
